newsitem.title: TANZANIA: Tanzania and Zanzibar agree on VAT introduction.
newsitem.headline: Tanzania and Zanzibar agree on VAT introduction.

text.p: Mainland Tanzania and union partner Zanzibar islands have agreed to coordinate the timing and rate for a Value Added Tax (VAT) launch scheduled for July 1998, a senior IMF official said on Wednesday.

"Zanzibar has come on board with VAT. The understanding is Zanzibar will adopt the same timetable and same rate," said Festus Osunsade, the senior representative for the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in Tanzania.
The rate for Tanzania's VAT was expected to be in close proximity to rates operating in Kenya and Uganda of 15 percent and 17.5 percent, respectively.
"It will eliminate so called nuisance taxes. Once you have VAT, it means no more stamp duty, hotel levy and single transaction tax," Osunsade said.
Combined, the three taxes total more than 30 percent.

Osunsade said the agreement to harmonise VAT followed a week of high-level discussions between senior IMF officials, Tanzania and Zanzibar. Zanzibar is semi-autonomous but forms part of the United Republic of Tanzania.
He said the agreement on VAT marked an important development and would help to prevent the re-emergence of an infamous channel of tax evasion known locally as the "Zanzibar route."
Harmonisation of import tarriffs was agreed to earlier this year. The "Zanzibar route" thrived by offering importers a lower tax rate than the official rate in force on the mainland.

"The Zanzibar route was also used to evade taxation because there are no pre-shipment inspection agencies like SGS (Societe Generale Surveillance) in Zanzibar," said a government parliamentary report into corruption, dated September 1996.
The only pre-shipment inspection applies to government goods and not those intended for the private sector.
In 1964, following a bloody revolution, Zanzibar and Pemba islands joined with the republic of Tanganyika to form the United Republic of Tanzania.

Taxation has emerged as a major political issue in Tanzania. Local manufacturers complain that the tax system is too complicated and offered little incentive for the creation of thriving home-grown industries.

On Wednesday, the IMF's deputy director for fiscal affairs, Jeffry Davis and other senior IMF officials held talks with Tanzanian President Benjamin Mkapa to discuss a wide range of economic issues including taxation.

The talks focused on recent lobbying efforts by the local business community for tax concessions and a draft bill designed to appease their concerns. The IMF is known to be concerned that the bill in its present form contained what one official described as "too many giveaways."
